Role of copper and cerium species in Cu/CeZSM catalysts for direct methane to methanol reaction: Insights of structure–activity relationship Pranay Rajendra Chandewar Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Debaprasad Shee Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad, Kandi, Sangareddy 502 284, Telangana, India Department of Chemical Engineering Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad Kandi Sangareddy 502 284 Telangana India Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad, Kandi, Sangareddy 502 284, Telangana, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The direct methane to methanol (DMTM) conversion was studied in a fixed bed reactor under varying reaction parameters including temperature, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) and CH4:O2 over several CeO2-ZSM5, CeO2-SiO2 and CeO2-Al2O3 supported CuO catalysts prepared by wetness impregnation method and characterized by several techniques including N2 adsorption desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), ultraviolet visible spectroscopy (UV–vis), temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) and CO-diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFT) studies. The characterization results confirm the formation of bis(µ-oxo) dicopper or mono-(µ-oxo) dicopper species considered as the active sites for the DMTM reaction. Moreover, various copper (Cu2+, Cu+ and Cu0) and cerium (Ce3+ and Ce4+) species are coexisted in a redox cycle equilibrium (Cu+ + Ce4+ ⇌ Cu2+ + Ce3+) depending on CeO2 loading. XPS studies indicates the generation of lattice and adsorbed oxygen species on deposition of CeO2 and their ratio varied with the CeO2 loading. Moreover, the different cerium species induces charge unbalance, oxygen vacancies, and formation of unsaturated chemical bonds on the catalyst’s surface. The deposition of CeO2 and CuO incorporates more Lewis’s acid sites in xCu/yCe-ZSM5 composite catalysts and even formation of additional Lewis’s acid sites originated from exchanged copper species. The various copper and cerium species formed in the composite catalysts strongly influenced the methane molecule activation, and selectivity and yield of methanol. The surface Cu2+ species promotes the formation of methanol and prevents the methanol overoxidation forming oxygenates and carbon dioxide. In addition to the Cu2+ species, the lattice and adsorbed oxygen generated on deposition of CeO2 also influence the formation and oxidation of methanol. Thus, optimum surface concentration of Cu2+ and lattice to adsorbed oxygen maximizes the yield of methanol. The process parameters also the affect the methane conversion and methanol selectivity and yield. The methanol selectivity of 6.34 % with methane conversion of 37.89 % was achieved over 20Cu/15CeZ catalysts at 873 K, 1030 ml hr-1 gcat−1 and CH4:O2 = 2:1. A plausible reaction mechanism of oxidation of methane to methanol based on the activity results and in-situ DRFIT studies of methanol oxidation. Keywords Methane Methanol Copper oxide Cerium oxide HZSM-5 XPS CO-DRIFT Lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio Data availability Additional data are available in supplementary information 1 Introduction Natural gas is being considered as promising substitute for the petroleum based resources due to its abundant reserves and limited crude oil resources [1]. While methane being a more potent contributor to greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions than CO2 calls for the global need to efficiently utilize this most valuable industry feedstock. Methane (major component of natural gas) valorisation to value added chemicals [2] proved to be a promising solution in utilising the most valuable stranded methane gas. This will help in achieving the global goal of attaining carbon neutrality. Recent technological advancements in natural gas exploration and production led to the regaining of methane abundant shale gas reserves [3]. However, the natural gas (methane) conversion remains a challenge. It is difficult to maintain the cost competitiveness of the natural gas (methane) derivatives (such as chemicals and liquid fuels) in comparison to other fossil fuels because of the challenges associated with the storage and energy-intensive transportation process from remote places [4]. Thus, a huge amount of natural gas is being flared itself at the production site causing large amount of CO2 emissions. It has been estimated that in the year 2021, about 144 billion cubic meters of gas have been flared accounting for 40 % of total indirect emissions from the global oil supply [5]. Hence the alternative approaches for methane conversion through less energy intensive routes are highly desirable. Direct methane to methanol (DMTM) conversion is considered as promising process for methane valorisation. In comparison to other methane derived oxygenates, methanol is the most valuable feedstock used to produce olefins (32 %), formaldehyde (23 %), acetic acid (8 %), and also in transport fuels via MTBE (11 %), biodiesel (3 %) and by partial blending or complete replacement (11 %) [6]. The market demand of methanol touched 106 million tonnes in 2021 with its growing demand at nearly double rate over the previous decade [6]. Moreover, the availability of huge natural gas reserves of about 198.9 trillion cubic meters for the year 2018 [7] makes the DMTM process as one of efficient way in solving the global issue of both environment and economy. The DMTM process is yet to be achieved under mild reaction conditions and is therefore not industrially viable at present. However, the conventional two-step process to produce methanol from methane via methane reforming to syngas which is catalytically converted over ZnO/Cr2O3 and Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts, respectively [8] is highly energy intensive process being running at an elevated temperature of around 1073–1273 K. Thus, DMTM process is a desired alternative to produce various fine chemicals and building block chemicals. Various technological pathways are being explored for DMTM such as plasma technologies, photocatalysis, water oxidation under supercritical condition, membrane technology, and biocatalysis [9]. However, the trade-off between methanol selectivity and methane conversion still remains the major challenge [10]. Moreover, the C–H bond activation of methane molecule requires high reaction temperature because of remarkable thermodynamic stability of methane molecule and over oxidation of the desired product methanol to oxygenates and carbon oxides (COx), reduces the selectivity of desired product [11]. Hence several researchers are focusing on catalysts development by mimicking the active sites of methane monooxygenease enzymes which converts the methane to methanol with very high selectivity at ambient conditions [11]. For this reason, extensive research is being focused on discovering of highly active and selective catalysts that can effectively promote methane conversion with high selectivity and yield of targeted product methanol. Various types of catalysts investigated include first-row transition metal oxides (e.g. Ti, V, Cr, Cu, Mn, Mo, Co, Fe, Zn, and Sc), noble metals (Rh, Pd, Pt, Au etc.) and their combinations. Collection of noble metals and transition metal oxides in the bimetallic (Au-Pd/TiO2) and trimetallic (Cu-Au-Pd/TiO2) oxides catalysts formulation was found to be effective in activation of methane. Unfortunately, the high price of noble metals restrict their application at large scale [12]. Hence the formulation of composite catalysts is focused on abundant and inexpensive transition metal oxides and reducing the noble metals content in the composite catalysts and making them more effective for the catalytic conversion of methane to methanol. Among the various transitional metal oxides, Fe and Cu oxides are well studied for DMTM. In recent past researcher have found extensive interests in studying copper-exchanged zeolites to bio-mimicking the active sites present in MMO (methane monooxygenase) enzymes. The active sites identified in MMO are diiron and dicopper oxygen bridges [13]. Considering the various proposed Cu oxide and zeolite combinations, the microporous zeolites such as ZSM-5 and mordenite (MOR) can form the active centres such as [Cu2(µ-O)2]2+, [Cu2(µ-O)]2+, [Cu3(µ-O)3]2+, or even CuOx clusters upon high-temperature activation in an oxidative environment. These active centres are eventually responsible for C–H bond activation present in methane [13 14 15]. Apart from the MFI framework, Cu metal oxide modified various frameworks of zeolites including mordenite(MOR), ferrierite (FER), chabazite (CHA), faujasite (FAU), beta (BEA), Linde type L (LTL), mazzite (MAZ), ZSM-18 (MEI), beryllophosphate-H (BPH), heulandite (HEU), etc. were studied for DMTM [16]. Specifically, metal exchanged ZSM-5, and MAZ zeolites showed better performance for methane activation. These zeolites affect the reactivity of metal or metal oxide active sites in metal-exchanged zeolites with few important characteristics including zeolites confinement, geometry, and affinity of active sites to hydrogen [17]. Past studies suggested that the inclusion of Cu2+ species helps in tuning the methanol selectivity by inhibiting its overoxidation to formic acid [18 19 20]. Newton et al. reported that the reaction mechanism is greatly influenced by Cu+/Cu2+ redox pair [21]. Hence speciation of Cu species in zeolite is of significant importance in assessing the performance of the DMTM process. On the other hand, the redox nature of non-stoichiometric cerium oxide originated from Ce3+ to Ce4+ transformations allow for easy oxygen storage and mobility. Hence the redox active non stoichiometric ceria and ceria-based mixed oxides are considered as promising catalysts support materials for the development of multi-functional supported metal oxide catalysts [22]. For example, cerium-based oxides find wide application in many catalytic processes including automotive exhaust catalytic converters, hydrocarbon reforming, and reverse water gas shift reactions [23]. However, very few studies demonstrated the detailed experimental performance of cerium-based catalysts for DMTM. Pablo G et al. showed that CeO2 (1 1 1) supported Ni catalysts executes a catalytic cycle for the formation of methanol at low temperatures in presence of oxygen and water [24]. A recent study showed the effect of CeO2 nanoparticle sizes on the methanol yield. It was noticed that methanol yield increases with decreasing the size of CeO2 nanoparticles. However DFT results showed that the edge and corner sites of CeO2 nanoparticles are turned out as potential active sites for the formation of methanol [25]. A recent study showed that an inverse CeO2/Cu2O/Cu (1 1 1) catalyst was capable of activating methane at room temperature and it was also concluded that CeO2/Cu2O interface is capable of binding and dissociating the methane molecule [26]. Furthermore Liu et al. [27] studied the role of water in tuning the selectivity of methanol over CeO2/Cu2O/Cu(1 1 1) catalyst. Theoretical studies showed that dissociation of water results in the formation of hydroxyl species which play dual role. Firstly, it blocks the O-O bond cleavage which would otherwise lead to overoxidation of methoxy groups into CO and CO2. Whereas it also promotes the formation of surface methoxy and accelerates the conversion of these methoxy species to methanol. It is evident from the above discussion that activation of methane molecule and overoxidation of desired product methanol are important aspects to consider during searching for appropriate catalysts. Various copper species play an important role in activating the methane molecule and overoxidation of methanol. Moreover, the redox and, oxygen storage and mobility properties of non-stoichiometric ceria are also important to explore for methane partial oxidation to produce methanol. In the present investigation, various CuO catalysts supported over CeO2 impregnated HZSM-5, SiO2 and Al2O3 were prepared and tested for DMTM reaction in a micro fixed bed reactor operating under different reaction conditions. The physico-chemical and redox properties of these prepared catalysts as determined from various characterization were correlated with the activity of these catalysts to explore the insights of the DMTM reaction. Moreover, the role of various copper species and nature of oxygen (adsorbed or lattice) on the methane molecule activation, and selectivity of methanol were delineated to understand the mechanistic aspect of the DMTM reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials ZSM-5 zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3 = 23, CBV2314) was purchased from Zeolyst International, USA. Copper (II) nitrate hemi (pentahydrate) and cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma-Aldrich) were used as metal precursors for copper (Cu) and cerium (Ce), respectively. Methane (purity 99.99 %) and oxygen gasses (purity 99.99 %) were used as reactants. Prior to use, ZSM-5 was heat treated at 823 K for 6 h and the other chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalysts Preparation Various CuO catalysts supported on CeO2-ZSM5 were prepared in two steps. First, the Ce was impregnated onto ZSM5 (Zeolyst, SiO2/Al2O3 = 23) zeolite followed by impregnation of Cu oxide over as prepared CeO2-ZSM5 support via wetness impregnation method. Typically, the measured quantity of the respective metal precursors was dissolved in millipore water to make the metal precursor solution. Then, the prepared precursor solution was intimately mixed with the predetermined amount of prepared support. The excess amount of water was evaporated by heating the mixture at 383 K followed by drying overnight at 393 K. The dried material was thoroughly ground into fine powder. The powder material was finally calcined in a muffle furnace at 823 K for 6 h using a heating ramp of 1 K min−1. The final prepared catalysts are denoted as xCu/yCeZ where ‘x’ and ‘y’ denote wt.% of total Cu and Ce loading (x = 5, to 25 wt%) and (y = 5 to 20 wt%), whereas CeZ denotes CeO2-ZSM5 support. The Cu oxide catalysts supported on CeO2-SiO2 (CeS), CeO2-Al2O3 (CeA) and ZSM5 (Z) were also prepared for comparison purpose following the above-mentioned method. 2.3 Catalysts characterisation N2 physisorption studies were carried out at 77 K in a Micromeritics ASAP2020 physisorption analyzer to evaluate the specific surface area and pore size distribution (PSD) of all the prepared catalysts. Before the analysis, all the prepared catalysts were subjected to degassing at 473 K for 5 h to eliminate moisture or any residual impurities. The specific surface area was estimated using the multipoint Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation and adsorption isotherm data acquired within the relative pressure (P/P0) ranging from 0.05 to 0.3. PSD was evaluated using the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) technique. The t-plot method was employed to determine the specific micropore area. The volume liquid nitrogen adsorbed at P/Po = 1.0 (approx.) was considered as the respective catalyst pore volume. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of all the prepared catalysts were recorded in a X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Smart Lab, Japan) fitted with monochromatized Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) source and D/teX ultra 250 detector. The diffractometer was functioned at 45 kV voltage and 30 mA current, and data were collected in the 2θ range of 10 to 90o at a scanning speed of 2o min−1. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the xCu/yCeZ catalysts were collected under ambient conditions using Bruker TENSOR 37 FITR spectrometer in the wavenumber ranging from 400-4000 cm−1. Prior to collection of spectra, pellets were prepared by mixing powder catalyst with spectroscopic grade KBr and the spectra were recorded against separately acquired KBr background and averaging of 256 no. of scans and 4 cm−1 of spectral resolution. The IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed catalysts were recorded to understand the characteristics of acid sites. The powder catalyst was mixed with few drops of pyridine and kept it for 12 h, and then excess pyridine was removed by heating at 383 K in a hot air oven for 1.5 h prior to making pellet for collecting the spectra. The IR spectra were collected following similar procedure under the similar conditions as mentioned above. The Ultraviolet visible (UV–vis) spectra of xCu/yCeZ catalysts were acquired in a PerkinElmer UV–vis NIR spectrophotometer (Model no: Lamda 365) from 200 to 1100 nm wavelength range. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were collected using Axis Supra spectro (Kratos Analytical) spectrometer fitted with a monochromatized Al Kα radiation source (1486.69 eV). Peaks were deconvoluted using the XPSPEAK 41 software, and the XPS data were processed using linear backdrop and Lorentzian-Gaussian mathematical function. The binding energy (BE) of respective elements was referenced with the BE of C1s at 284.73 eV. Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) studies using hydrogen were performed in an AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) chemisorption analyser. Before the analysis, the powder catalyst was pretreated at 473 K for 1 h in argon flow to eliminate moisture and residual impurities. The temperature was then decreased to 373 K while continuing the f argon gas flow and subsequently, the gas flow was switched to 10 vol.% H2/Ar gas mixture. Then the temperature was increased to 1073 K using 10 K/min heating rate under the flow of 10 vol.% H2/Ar. The consumption of hydrogen was continuously recorded using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The CO adsorption study was carried out using Bruker TENSOR 37 FITR spectrometer connected with high temperature reaction chamber (Harrick Scientific Products Inc, Model no: HVC-DRP-4), praying mantis (Harrick Scientific Products Inc) and automatic temperature controller (Harrick Scientific Products Inc., Model No. ATC-024–3). The IR spectra were collected from 1000-4000 cm−1 wavenumber range and averaging of 256 no. of scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to adsorption measurement, the sample was treated at 823 K for 1 h in the high temperature reaction chamber under the flow of pure N2 gas. The DRIFT spectra of adsorbed species were recorded at different temperature ranging from ambient to 773 K in continuous flow of mixture of CO and N2 gases. The CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) study was carried out using chemisorption equipment (BELCAT II, Microtrac BEL Corporation) equipped with a TCD detector to determine the basicity of the representative catalysts. About 80 mg of catalyst sample was pretreated at 473 K in flowing of He for 1 h to eliminate adsorbed moisture and any other residual impurities. Before the commencement of analysis, the catalyst temperature was lowered to 373 K in flowing of He and subsequently 10 vol.% CO2/He gas mixture was fed at a flow rate of 30 ml/min. The catalyst was heated to 973 K using a heating rate of 10 K/min. The desorbed CO2 was detected using a TCD. 2.4 Catalyst activity evaluation The activity of the prepared catalysts for DMTM was evaluated in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor (SS make, 1-inch ID) under wide range of process parameters. The catalyst bed was made with the physical mixture of powder catalyst and inert quartz taken in the ratio of 1:4. The catalyst bed was held by the layers of quartz wool from both sides of the bed, and it was positioned in the isothermal zone of the vertically placed tubular furnace. The loaded catalyst was then pre-treated for 1 h at the desired reaction temperature in flowing of N2 (15 ml min−1) and O2 (15 ml min−1). The flow rate of all the pretreatment and reactive gases was precisely controlled by individual thermal mass flow controller (MFC, EL-FLOW, Bronkhorst). After the pretreatment of the loaded catalyst, the reactant gasses mixture (N2, O2, and CH4) were introduced in specific ratio maintaining the total flow rate of 60 ml min−1. The liquid samples were periodically collected for analysis for a period of 5 h of reaction time. The fraction permanent gases in the gaseous product mixture (H2, N2, O2, CH4, and CO2) were quantitatively analysed using online micro gas chromatograph (Micro GC, Agilent 490C) equipped with TCD, Pora plot U (PPU), and CP-molsieve (MS5A) columns. The light hydrocarbon gases (C1-C2) fraction in gaseous product mixture were quantitively analysed using online GC (Shimadzu, Nexis GC-2030) fitted with flame ionisation detector (FID) and connected to GS-GasPro capillary column (Agilent 30 m x 0.32 mm). The composition collected liquid products was determined using an offline GC-FID (Agilent 7890B GC) connected to a DB-WAX capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 µm). The gas chromatography mass spectroscopy (GC–MS, Shimazdu GCMS QP2010 Ultra) was used to identify the components of gaseous and liquid products and additionally, pure compounds were also used to reconfirm the identity of the products. The representative chromatograms for all gaseous and liquid products are shown in Figure S1. The carbon balance calculations were performed for all the conducted experimental runs and errors obtained were within ± 5 %. Reproducibility, and stability test were also conducted at optimum reaction conditions using the best performing catalysts in terms of methanol yield (%). The methane conversion and product selectivity were calculated using following equations, C H 4 C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( I n i t i a l m o l e s o f m e t h a n e ) - ( F i n a l m o l e s o f m e t h a n e ) ( I n i t i a l m o l e s o f m e t h a n e ) ∗ 100 P r o d u c t s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = n ∗ ( m o l e s o f p r o d u c t f o r m e d ) ( T o t a l m o l e s o f c a r b o n c o n v e r t e d ) ∗ 100 Where ‘n’ is number of carbon atoms n = 1 for CH4, HCHO, HCOOH, CH3OH, CO2 and n = 2 for. C2H6 and C2H4. Further to determine the stability of methanol over the catalysts, the methanol oxidation reaction was also performed using the fixed bed reactor setup with the best performing catalyst (20Cu/15CeZ). The methanol was pumped at flow rate of 0.1 ml/min using HPLC pump (Lab alliance Series-I) through preheater operated at 473 K. However, the WHSV was not the same for methanol oxidation reaction and methane partial oxidation reaction. Product analysis was performed as mentioned above. 2.5 In-situ DRIFT study of methanol oxidation reaction The in-situ DRIFT study of methanol oxidation was performed using the Bruker TENSOR 37 FTIR spectrometer connected with high temperature reaction chamber (Harrick Scientific Products Inc, Model no: HVC-DRP-4), praying mantis (Harrick Scientific Products Inc) and automatic temperature controller (Harrick Scientific Products Inc., Model No. ATC-024–3). The IR spectra were recorded in the wavenumber ranging from 1000-4000 cm−1 at resolution of 4 cm−1 and an accumulation of 256 scans. The catalyst was packed in the high temperature reaction chamber, pretreated at 823 K for 1 h and then cooled to ambient temperature. The DRIFT spectra were recorded at different temperatures varying from 298 K to 673 K (20 min. of hold time at each temperature) with methanol being carried into the reaction chamber by nitrogen and oxygen flowing through a bubbler. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts Characterizations The textural properties of pure ZSM5 and CuO catalysts deposited on different supports (CeO2-ZSM5, and ZSM5, CeO2-SiO2 and CeO2-Al2O3) were determined using N2 adsorption–desorption measurements and are represented in Table 1 and S1. The estimated surface areas of pure ZSM5, SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 are 305 m2/g, 256 m2/g and 271 m2/g, respectively. Among the CuO catalysts supported on various supports, the 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst showed the highest BET surface area than the 20Cu/15CeS and 20Cu/15CeA catalysts. As shown in Figure S2A, all the isotherms are resembled of the type IV isotherms based on IUPAC classification with hysteresis loop and an extended capillary condensation step in the relative pressure range of P/Po = 0.44 to 0.9 for xCu/yCeZ catalysts, P/Po = 0.65 to 0.9 for 20Cu/15CeA supported catalyst and P/Po = 0.8 to 0.9 for 20Cu/15CeS catalysts. All xCu/yCeZ catalysts along with pure ZSM-5 showed type IV isotherm and hysteresis loop in a relative pressure range (P/Po) between 0.45 and 0.9 which are illustrated in Figs. 1 and S2 B. All the xCu/yCeZ catalysts showed mesopores of average size of about 4 nm which can be seen from PSD as depicted in Figure S3A and B. However, the peak at 4 nm in the PSD are attributed to physical mesopores while being strictly associated with the nature of the adsorbed phase (especially for MFI-type zeolites) [28]. As shown in Table 1 , the BET surface area and total pore volume of 15CeZ and 20Cu/Z showed a lower value than that of pristine ZSM-5. This decline in surface area and pore volume implies that the CeO2 species blocking the ZSM-5 micropores [23 29]. However in 20Cu/Z, this can be attributed to Cu species covering the external surface of ZSM-5 [30] and clogging the micropores as well as mesopores. The BET surface area was continued to decrease further with increasing both the Cu and Ce metal oxides loading. The external surface area and micropore surface area decrease with raising the Ce metal oxide loading. However, the micropore surface area remains constant for CeZ supported catalysts with Cu metal loading from 5 wt.% to 20 wt.% and later decreases at higher Cu metal loading of 25 wt%. However, the external surface area continues to decrease upto the 25 wt.% Cu metal loading. These observations indicate that Cu species are preferably occupied in mesopores and or macropores at Cu metal loading up to 20 wt% and are also deposited in micropores of CeZ support beyond 20 wt.% of Cu metal loading. Furthermore, there has been an insignificant change in the total pore volume of xCu/yCeZ catalysts. The powder XRD patterns of xCu/yCeZ catalysts are presented in Figures 2 and S4(A and B). The diffraction pattern of pure ZSM-5 shows characteristic peaks attributed to MFI topological structure of ZSM-5 zeolites at 2θ values of 14.77° (0 3 1), 23.14° (5 0 1), 23.3° (0 5 1), 23.74° (1 5 1), 23.96° (3 0 3) and 24.44° (1 3 3) [ICCD PDF card no. 00–042-0023]. The intensity of peaks in the 2θ range of 22° to 25° decreases upon metal impregnation resulting in decreasing crystallinity of ZSM-5 [31]. However, no changes in characteristic peaks of ZSM-5 were observed indicating no alteration of ZMS-5 framework structure on deposition of metal oxide. The relative crystallinity determined from the collected diffraction data is tabulated in Table 1. The CeZ supports exhibit peaks at 2θ of 28.56° (1 1 1), 33.07° (2 0 0), 47.44° (2 2 0), and 56.23° (3 1 1) corresponding to the cubic crystal structure of CeO2 [ICCD PDF card no. 00–034-0394]. The Cu/Z catalyst exhibits typical diffraction peaks at 2θ of 35.5° (0 0 2) and 38.7° (1 1 1) of monoclinic crystal structure of CuO [ICCD PDF card no. 00–048-1548]. In case of xCu/yCeZ catalysts, the characteristics diffraction peaks of both CuO and CeO2 species are distinctly visible along with the typical diffraction peaks of ZSM-5 and intensity of these peaks rises with increasing the respective metal oxides loading. The FT-IR spectra of CuO catalysts supported over CeZ, CeS and CeA including respective pure supports in the hydroxyl (O–H) (3100–4000 cm−1) and fingerprint region (400–2000 cm−1) are depicted in Fig. 3 (A and B), S5 (A and B) and S6 (A and B). The pure ZSM5 showed IR bands at 451, 548, 793, 1060–1130 (broad), 1225, and 1630 cm−1. The IR bands present at 1060–1130 (broad) and 451 cm−1 are because of the asymmetric and T-O bending vibration of (Si, Al)O4 internal tetrahedra of ZSM-5. However, the IR band around 740 cm−1 corresponding to symmetric mode of vibration is not discernible in the spectra of ZSM5 [32]. Other characteristics IR bands showed at 1225, 793, and 548 cm−1 are because of the vibrations corresponding to the external linkages between tetrahedral and thus sensitive to the zeolite framework structure [32]. Detail IR bands assignment of other pure supports is summarised in Table S2, S3 and S4. As shown in Fig. 3B, the weak band appeared at 692 cm−1 in CeZ supports in addition to the bands attributed to pure ZSM-5 is likely due to cerium silicate species [23] and intensity of this band continued to increase with increasing the CeO2 loading as presented in Fig. S6B. The IR spectrum of Cu/Z shows a weak shoulder at 589 cm−1 associated with the Cu–O vibration in bulk CuO [33]. As presented in Fig. 3(a), the band at 3646 cm−1 shows the decrease in intensity after CuO deposition, which is attributed to the exchange of acidic protons with Cu species [34]. The nature of the acidic sites (Bronsted and Lewis acid sites) present in the xCu/yCeZ catalysts was examined by collecting the FT-IR spectra of the pyridine adsorbed catalysts, which are displayed in Fig. 4 and S7(A and B). The pyridine adsorbed catalysts exhibited IR bands at 1448 cm−1, 1492 cm−1, and 1546 cm−1, corresponds to the Bronsted acid sites (B), Bronsted and Lewis acid sites (B + L), and Lewis acid sites (L), respectively [35 36]. IR spectra of pure ZSM-5 in the hydroxyl region show IR band at 3434 cm−1, 3611 cm−1 and 3646 cm−1. The IR band at 3611 cm−1 is related to the Bronsted acid sites originated from Si-OH-Al linkages of zeolite framework and IR band at 3646 cm−1 is because of the extra framework Al3+ species of Lewis acid character present in the zeolite [30]. It is evident that deposition of CeO2 increases the IR band intensity corresponding to the Lewis acidity. However, Cu/Z catalyst shows more Lewis acidity than ZSM-5 and CeZ which might be due to the increased amount of CuO oxide Lewis acid character [37] . The IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed xCu/yCeZ catalysts suggests the presence of both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites. A slight shift of IR band at 1448 cm−1 to higher wavenumber was observed for 5Cu/CeZ catalyst and this band was continued to shift to higher wavenumber with increase in the CuO loading. The gradual shift of this band indicates the formation of the coordination bond between copper ions (Cu+) and the nitrogen atom of pyridine heterocyclic ring [38]. Furthermore, the IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed Cu/Z confirms the formation of additional band at 1618 cm−1 and this band is visible in the IR spectra of all CuO deposited catalysts. This IR band at 1618 cm−1 is attributed to the Lewis acid sites generated due to the formation of exchanged copper species [37]. The decrease in Bronsted acid sites (1546 cm−1) on deposition of CuO also indicates replacement of this acid sites with exchanged copper species and generation of additional Lewis’s acid sites (1448 and 1618 cm−1) [38]. Moreover, the B/L ratio estimated from pyridine FTIR data are summarised in Table 1. The B/L ratio drops drastically on deposition of metal oxides as compared to pure ZSM-5. However, the variation of B/L ratio was not significant on the variation of CuO and CeO2 loading. The UV–vis spectroscopic analysis was performed to better understand the nature and coordination of copper and cerium oxide species. The UV–vis spectra of prepared catalysts including pure ZSM-5 are shown in Figures 5 and S8 (A, B and C). In case of CeZ supports, the characteristic bands appeared at 235 nm and 327 nm are attributed to the charge transfer between the oxygen ligand and Ce3+ [39] and to the charge transfer caused by the lone pair electrons of oxygen to Ce4+, respectively [3940]. However, the appearance of a band below 250 nm in UV–vis spectra is mostly because of the incorporation of metal atoms into the framework of ZSM-5 zeolites [39 41]. The band intensity at 235 nm tends to rise with increasing the CeO2 loading. For Cu/Z catalyst, the strong absorption band at 229 nm, weak band at 415 nm, and broad band above 600 nm were observed. The appearance of band at 229 nm represents the O2– → Cu2+ transitions of Cu2+ species in tetragonal configuration, which is well-dispersed in the form of clusters on the surface of ZSM-5 grains [42]. The band above 600 nm is originated due to the d-d transitions of octahedrally coordinated and more or less tetragonally distorted Cu2+ species corresponding to the CuO phase [42 43 44 45]. Whereas, the weak shoulder at 415 nm can be assigned to the charge transfer band from Cu to O either in bis(µ-oxo) dicopper or in mono-(µ-oxo) dicopper species [43 44]. However, the previous studies suggest that these Cu species act as an active site for the DMTM [46]. As shown in Fig. 5 for xCu/CeZ catalysts, the bands appeared between 229 nm and 235 nm can be related to the charge transfer transition of O2– → Cu+/Cu2+ and O2– → Ce3+. However, it is difficult to discriminate these transitions probably because of the electronic interaction between Cu2+ and Ce3+ ions, resulting in the appearance of band at a lower wavelength [42]. In order to determine the surface chemical state, the prepared catalysts were subjected to XPS analysis, and the spectra obtained are shown in Fig. 6 . The complete survey spectra of ZSM-5 show the occurrence of the Si(2p) and Al(2p) at BE of 103.48 eV and 75.47 eV, respectively [47]. The O1s spectra of ZSM-5 show only peak at BE of 532.55 eV which is attributed to the lattice oxygen species in zeolite [48 49]. In case of Cu/Z, no additional peak appears in O1s spectra (Fig. 6A). In contrast, deposition of CeO2 shows the emergence of peaks corresponding to lattice oxygen (O2–) species from cerium oxides and adsorbed oxygen species, at BE values of 528.91 eV and at 530.15 eV, respectively [50]. A previous study suggests that Ce3+ induces charge imbalance, oxygen vacancies, and formation of unsaturated chemical bonds on the catalyst's surface, which result in increase of concentration of chemisorbed oxygen or weakly bonded oxygen species [51]. These oxygen species play a crucial role in the catalytic oxidation reaction. In particular, adsorbed oxygens are effective for oxidation reaction due to their higher mobility [52] and ability to interact with the organic molecules [28]. The O1s spectra of xCu/yCeZ catalysts depicted in Fig. 6A and S9A show two peaks similar to Ce/Z together with the primary peak assigned to the lattice oxygen originated from the ZSM-5 zeolite structure. As shown in Figure S9B, the peaks corresponding to the lattice and adsorbed oxygen species are found to be consistence for oxidised 20Cu/15CeS and 20Cu/15CeA catalysts. The lattice oxygen species to adsorbed oxygen species ratio estimated from their respective areas is tabulated in Table 2 and exhibits the highest value for 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst. Fig. 6C and S9(E and F) represent the Ce 3d core level XPS spectra. Upon deconvolution, the CeZ supported CuO catalysts show multiple splitting patterns of Ce3+ and Ce4+ due to the electron correlation phenomenon [53]. The peaks at BE of 880.9 eV and 884.57 eV corresponds to the 3d5/2 core level spectra of Ce3+ species and the peaks at BE of 899.64 eV and 903.83 eV are related to the 3d3/2 core level spectra of Ce3+ species. The 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 core level spectra of Ce4+ exhibit peaks at BE of 882.09 eV and 900.59 eV, respectively [41 53 54]. The satellites peaks of 3d5/2 level of Ce4+ were observed at BE of 888.54 eV, and 897.78 eV whereas the peaks at BE of 906.9 eV and 916.35 eV correspond to the Ce3d3/2 level of Ce4+ [41 52]. The peak at BE of 916.35 eV is characteristics of Ce4+ [25] . Additional information regarding peak assignment for all the catalysts is presented in Table S5. It is clear form Table S5 that Ce3+ and Ce4+ species are coexisted in all the prepared catalysts facilitating the chemical redox cycles [28 55 56]. The relative percentage surface compositions of Ce3+ and Ce4+ species were calculated from the relative area of the corresponding peaks and are summarised in Table 2. However, it was observed that the concentration of Ce3+ species was increased on deposition of CuO on 15CeZ and the Ce3+ concentration had remained nearly unchanged even after increasing the Cu loading. However, the Ce3+ concentration was increased with the increased in Ce metal loading (Table 2) suggesting the creation of more oxygen vacancies [57]. However, the Ce4+ species was the predominant species in all the prepared catalysts. Fig. 6B and S9(C and D) exhibit the Cu2p core level XPS spectra of prepared catalysts. It was reported that the Cu2p3/2 transition occurs at lower BE than 933 eV for metallic copper (Cu0) and Cu2O (Cu+) species and the transition shifts to higher BE values than 933 eV for Cu2+ species [58]. The deconvolution of Cu2p spectra resulted peaks at BE of 932.6 eV and 952.61 eV belonging to the Cu2p3/2 level of Cu+ [59 60] and may be due to the reduced copper species (Cu0), respectively [61]. The peaks at BE of 933.4 eV and 935.5 eV corresponds to agglomerated/bulk CuO species on catalyst surface [45 58] and isolated Cu2+ ion in octahedral coordination, respectively. Whereas the peak at BE of 954.74 eV is attributed to Cu2p1/2 level of Cu2+ [45]. The isolated Cu2+ ions in octahedral coordination are firmly attached to the zeolite framework [58]. The shake-up satellites peaks of Cu2+ are appeared at BE of 942.96 eV and 961.91 eV [52 62]. It is evident from Table 2 that the concentration of Cu2+ (%) species increases on deposition of Cu on CeO2-ZSM-5 in comparison to Cu/Z catalysts and the Cu2+ species concentration continues to increase further with the increase in CeO2 loading suggesting that certain fraction of Cu+ is oxidized to Cu2+. Moreover, the increase in the generation of Cu2+ species and Ce3+ species with the increase of CeO2 content is indicatory of the shifting of redox equilibrium (Cu+ + Ce4+ ⇌ Cu2+ + Ce3+) to the right side for CuO loaded CeO2-ZSM-5 catalysts [42]. The relative concentration of various Cu and Ce species are likely to alter under reaction conditions in comparison to ambient conditions. All these species remained in dynamic redox equilibrium under reaction conditions. Thus in-situ characterization of the catalyst under reaction conditions and correlating with the activity results could unravel the insights of the role of all these species towards the formation of different products both in selective and unselective route of DMTM process. This important in-situ characterization studies under reaction conditions can be considered as future scope. H2-TPR analysis was performed to investigate the reducibility of the catalysts and the obtained TPR profiles are shown in Fig. 7 and Figures S10(A,B and C). The H2-TPR profile of pure ZSM-5 shows no obvious peaks indicating the non-reducible of nature of ZSM-5 under this condition. The TPR profile of CeO2 shows reduction peaks in three different temperature ranges. The reduction peaks in the temperature range of 373–673 K, 673–873 K and above 873 K correspond to the reduction of Ce species deposited on the interface of ZSM-5, reduction of surface Ce species and reduction of Ce species in bulk phase, respectively [28 55 63]. As shown in Fig. S10A, the TPR profile of Ce-ZSM5 showed two peaks centred at 804 K and 1148 K because of the reduction of surface Ce species (i.e. Ce4+ to Ce3+) and the reduction of CeO2 species in bulk phase [64 65]. The H2-TPR profile of 20Cu/Z, 20Cu/15CeZ, 20Cu/15CeS and 20Cu/15CeA catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 and Figures S10(B and C). Two reduction peaks were noticed for Cu/Z catalysts at 531 K and 652 K corresponding to the two-step reduction of isolated Cu2+ to Cuo. The reduction peak showed at 531 K is attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ and reduction peak at 652 K corresponds to the reduction of Cu+ to Cuo [30 45]. It was observed that the Cu species over CeZ reduces at lower temperature in comparison to Cu species over pure ZSM-5, CeS and CeA suggesting enhancement of reducibility of Cu species in presence of CeO2 [44]. The in-situ DRIFT studies of CO adsorption was performed to explore the nature of surface Cu sites in supported Cu catalysts. The DRIFT spectra of adsorbed probe molecule CO on pure ZSM5, 15CeZ, 20CuZ and 20Cu/15CeZ catalysts at different temperature are shown in Fig. 8 and Figure S11(A, B and C) and the pure ZSM-5 and 15CeZ showed no characteristics IR bands corresponding to the CO adsorption in the wavenumber region of 2000–2300 cm−1. However, supported CuO catalysts showed several characteristics bands due to the adsorption of CO indicating presence of the Cu active species. The adsorption of CO on 20CuZ catalyst under ambient conditions leads to the appearance of a band at 2127 cm−1 due to the physically adsorbed CO [66]. This IR band shifts gradually to a higher wavenumber with raising the temperature to 423 K, and finally disappears at temperature of 448 K and above. At temperature of 323 K, two new IR bands appear at 2151 cm−1 and 2173 cm−1 corresponding to monocarbonyl Cu species (Cu+–CO) and dicarbonyl Cu species (Cu+(CO)2), respectively. However, some researchers also assign the band at 2173 cm−1 to Cu2+–CO [34 65 67 68 69 70] . The IR band at 2151 cm−1 appeared as a shoulder at 323 K and became a noticeable band at temperatures over 473 K. This band shifted to the higher wavenumber as the temperature increased to 773 K and finally appeared as broad band by overlapping with the band at 2127 cm−1 originated at low temperature. The band at 2173 cm−1 was visible till 423 K and completely disappeared beyond 473 K. The detailed peak assignment is summarized in Table S6. Similar characteristics IR bands of CO adsorbed Cu species were noticed for 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst suggesting the presence of Cu+ and Cu2+ species on catalysts as confirmed by XPS study. The CO2-TPD profiles of selective catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 and Figure S12, and the basicity values are tabulated in Table S9. The CO2-TPD profile shows two CO2 desorption peaks for each sample. The peak α (458 K– 471 K) and peak β (636 K – 688 K) represents the weakly and strongly adsorbed CO2 on the catalyst’s surface [71]. It was observed that 20Cu/15CeZ showed the highest total basicity (Table S9). Moreover, both the weak and strong basicity of 20Cu/15CeZ was higher than the other catalysts. The total basicity of 20Cu/15CeA and 20Cu/15CeS catalysts was lower than the 20Cu/15CeZ. However, 20Cu/15CeA and 20Cu/15CeS catalysts possess a higher amount of strong basic sites than the 20Cu/15CeZ (Table S10). (See Fig. 10 ). 3.2 Reaction studies The DMTM reaction was carried out in a continuous down flow fixed bed reactor over xCu/yCeZ (or S and A) catalysts under changing process parameters such as Cu loading (5 to 25 %), CeO2 loading (5 to 20 %), temperature (673 – 923 K), WHSV (655 – 1440 ml/h– 1 gcat−1) and CH4/O2 ratio. Various gaseous and liquid products formed in the present investigation were identified and quantified. Methanol, formaldehyde, and formic acid were the products formed in the liquid phase and carbon dioxide was formed as the major component in gas phase. Traces of hydrogen, ethane, and ethylene were also formed. The DMTM reaction was investigated in detailed to understand the effect of various reaction parameters on product distribution as discussed below. 3.2.1 Effect of support Figures 10 and S13 shows the performance of the DMTM reaction using CuO catalysts supported over CeS, CeZ, and CeA. All the catalysts were found to activate methane molecule and were effective for DMTM reaction. The 20Cu/15CeS catalyst showed less conversion for both methane and oxygen as compared to the other supported catalysts of similar Cu metal loading. The 20Cu/15CeS catalyst favoured the formation of formaldehyde with a selectivity of 3.54 % which is in accordance with the previous studies [72]. It was suggested that mesoporous silica as support (SBA-15) is more favourable for formaldehyde formation due to easy desorption of HCHO and inert nature of silica as support [46 72]. However, the 20Cu/15CeA catalyst showed overoxidation of methanol forming more formic acid. The overoxidation of methanol over 20Cu/15CeA catalyst compared to 20Cu/15CeS and 20Cu/15CeZ catalysts is due to the low Cu2+ species proportion and lower lattice to adsorbed oxygen species ratio as estimated from XPS studies. As previous studies reported that not only Cu2+ species prevents overoxidation of methanol resulting in the formation of formic acid [12 73 74]. However, the adsorbed oxygen plays significant role in oxidation of methanol [75 76]. Thus, the 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst performs well in achieving the high methanol selectivity. The methanol yield was 0.41 % and 0.57 % for 20Cu/CeS and 20Cu/15CeA catalysts, respectively. Furthermore, the basicity of 20 wt% of Cu catalysts supported over different supports also had influence on product distribution. The selectivity of methanol decreases at the expense of overoxidation leading to the formation of other oxygenates. It was observed that selectivity of formic acid was highest over Al2O3 supported catalysts which could be correlated with the presence of more strong basic sites than catalysts supported over SiO2 and ZSM5 as shown in Table S9. However, the 20Cu/15CeZ showed the highest yield of methanol (2.4 %) among all supported catalysts. Therefore, the CeZ was used as catalyst support for further assessment of the performance of DMTM reaction over various process parameters. 3.2.2 Effect of metal loading The methane molecule activation and selective oxidation to methanol provides the biggest challenge for the DMTM route. However, in the present study, it was shown that Cu/Z and xCu/yCeZ catalysts were effective in activating the methane molecule. Fig. 11 ,12, S14 and S15 show the catalytic performance of the xCu/yCeZ catalysts for DMTM conversion. The DMTM reaction was also carried out using pure ZSM-5 as reference and the corresponding results are reported in Table S7. The low conversion of methane over ZSM-5 and CeO2-ZSM5 supports as compared to corresponding supported CuO catalysts clearly indicates that CuO is active and effective for the activation of methane. However, the methane activation exhibited by ZSM-5 may be attributed to the molecular confinement effect within zeolites micropores [77]. In comparison to 20Cu/Z catalyst, the 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst showed superior methane activation activity leading to the higher methane conversion. The superior activity of 20Cu/15CeZ than that of 20Cu/Z catalysts towards methanol can be attributed to the presence of optimum concentration of Cu2+ and lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio as discussed later. In case of xCu/yCeZ catalysts, it was observed that with increase in Ce metal loading ranging from 5 to 15 wt%, the methanol selectivity significantly increases from 1.43 % to 6.34 % and further decreases for 20 wt% of Ce metal loading. While the formic acid selectivity continues to decrease with increase in Ce metal loading as shown in Fig. 11. The highest methanol yield (2.4 %) was achieved for xCu/yCeZ catalysts with 15 wt% of Ce metal loading. Therefore, to study the effect of Cu metal loading, the 15 wt% of Ce metal loading was deemed as an appropriate loading for yCeZ supports. As shown in Figure S15 and Fig. 12 , with an increase in Cu metal loading ranging from 5 wt% to 20 wt%, the methane conversion and methanol selectivity significantly increased. However, further increase in Cu loading resulted in a decrease in the methane conversion and methanol selectivity. The 20Cu/15CeZ appeared as the best-performing catalysts in the series producing the highest yield of methanol (2.4 %). However, the formaldehyde selectivity was noticed to enhance with increasing the Cu loading suggesting that both methanol and formaldehyde are formed as a result of series reactions. The formic acid selectivity was noticed to decline with increasing the Cu metal loading up to 20 wt%. However further increasing the Cu metal loading enhances the formic acid selectivity as shown in Fig. 12. The decrease in selectivity of methanol for 20Cu/15CeZ and 20Cu/20CeZ catalysts is at the expense of enhancement in selectivity of formic acid and CO2. The overoxidation of methanol leads to the formation of formic acid, which adsorbs on catalyst surface and or anchored to the catalyst surface as monodentate and bidentate formate species [78]. The complex of adsorbed formic acid and monodentate formate species renders additional stability to formic acid than the pure formic acid. However, the decomposition of complex of formic acid and monodentate formate species leads to the generation of gaseous formic acid whereas decomposition of bidentate formate species results in the formation of CO2. Thus, selectivity of methanol and formic acid followed opposite trend with increase in Cu loading upto 20 wt%. These observations can be correlated with the increase in concentration of Cu2+ species in the xCu/yCeZ catalysts as calculated from XPS data. The Cu2+ species increases with increasing the Cu loading and on Ce incorporation. Moreover, further increase of CeO2 loading slowly and gradually increases the concentration of Cu2+ species as shown in Table 2. Additionally, H2-TPR studies also confirmed that CeO2 incorporation enhances the reducibility of Cu species. Previous study conducted over Cu/Z catalyst for methane oxidation showed that deposition of Cu2+ increases the methanol selectivity by preventing overoxidation of methanol to formic acid [12 73 74]. Cu2+ species were also found to prevent the hydroxyl radical formation and inhibit the hydroxyl radical mediated oxidation of methane to methanol [77]. However, despite of higher surface composition of Cu2+ in 25Cu/15CeZ and 20Cu/20CeZ catalysts, the 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst performed well and resulted in lower formic acid selectivity. Correlation can be device between these observations with the ratio of lattice to adsorbed oxygen as summarised in Table 2. The lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio calculated from XPS data show maximum value for 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst. According to previous research, the partial oxidation of methane to methanol was found to be caused by both lattice (O2–) and adsorbed oxygen species. However, the adsorbed oxygen species promotes the methanol oxidation resulting in the formation of formic acid and CO2. As a result, tuning of lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio is essential for accomplishing the highest methanol selectivity [75 76 79]. Hence in DMTM reaction where faster oxidation of desired product (methanol) prevails, poses a challenge to its selectivity. The formation of active Cu2+ and appropriate lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio play a vital role in this regard. As a result, the highest methanol yield (2.4 %) was achieved over 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst by preventing methanol overoxidation resulting in the formation of formic acid and further to CO2. (See Figs. 13–16 .). As shown in Figure S15 and Fig. 12, with an increase in Cu metal loading ranging from 5 wt% to 20 wt%, the methane conversion and methanol selectivity significantly increased. However, further increase in Cu metal loading resulted in a decrease in the methane conversion and methanol selectivity. The 20Cu/15CeZ appeared as the best-performing catalysts in the series producing the highest yield of methanol (2.4 %). The higher activity of 20Cu/15CeZ could also be correlated with its higher total basicity as shown in Fig. 9 and Table S9. Both the amount of weak and strong basic sites was higher for 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst. However, the formaldehyde selectivity was noticed to enhance with increasing the Cu metal loading suggesting that both methanol and formaldehyde are formed as a result of series reactions. The formic acid selectivity was noticed to decline with increasing the Cu metal loading up to 20 wt%. The lower selectivity of formic acid could also be related to the increase in total basicity upto 20 wt% of Cu loading (20Cu/15CeZ) as shown in Table S9. However further increasing the Cu metal loading enhances the formic acid selectivity as shown in Fig. 12. The enhancement of formic acid selectivity may also be due to the drop in basicity beyond 20 wt% of Cu loading. The decrease in selectivity of methanol for 20Cu/25CeZ and 20Cu/20CeZ catalysts is at the expense of enhancement in selectivity of formic acid and CO2. 3.2.3 Effect of temperature The remarkable stability of the methane molecule makes the reaction temperature an essential process parameter for the C–H bond activation of methane. Thus, the effect of temperature was studied in the temperature range of 673 K to 923 K and the results are shown in Fig. 13 and S16. The conversion of methane raised significantly as the temperature was increased from 673 K to 873 K and remained unchanged at higher temperature. The maximum conversion of methane achieved was 37.89 % at 873 K. However, oxygen was completely converted at all reaction temperatures. The selectivity of methanol increases whereas the selectivity of formic acid decreases with increase in reaction temperature upto 873 K. On increasing the temperature beyond 873 K, the methanol overoxidation led to the formation of formic acid and CO2 resulting in drastic decline in methanol selectivity and higher selectivity of formic acid at these temperatures. The highest methanol yield of 2.4 % was obtained at an optimal reaction temperature of 873 K for 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst. The selectivity of formaldehyde reached the maximum value of 3.1 % at 823 K and showed a decreasing trend on further rise in temperature suggesting that the lower temperature favours the formation of formaldehyde. The selectivity of total oxygenates (CH3OH, HCHO, and HCOOH) was increased with an increase in temperature owing to increase in conversion of methanol. Whereas the selectivity of formic acid found to be highest at 923 K leading to the overoxidation of methanol. 3.2.4 Effect of WHSV The variation of product selectivity, methanol yield and methane conversion with WHSV was studied and the results are presented in Fig. 14 and Figures S17. The methane conversion considerably rises from 34.11 to 37.89 % as the WHSV increases from 1440 ml hr-1 gcat−1 to 1030 ml hr-1 gcat−1, and thereafter a steady methane conversion was realized. The maximum methane conversion of 37.89 % was realized at 1030 ml hr-1 gcat−1 leading to the highest yield of methanol (2.4 %). The total oxygenates (CH3OH, HCHO, and HCOOH) selectivity increase with a decrease in WHSV with an exception at 1440 ml hr-1 gcat−1 owing to less conversion. However, despite of increase in oxygenates selectivity, the yield of methanol was less because of the more formic acid and CO2 formation as a result of overoxidation. The formaldehyde selectivity also increases with decline in WHSV. This, observation can be correlated with an increase in the contact time of desired oxidized product (methanol) with the catalysts yielding over-oxidized products (HCHO, HCOOH and CO2). 3.2.5 Effect of CH4/O2 ratio Methane to oxygen ratio was considered as an important parameter to tune the selectivity of desired oxygenates (methanol and formaldehyde) by suppressing the deep oxidation to CO2. The influence of CH4/O2 ratio was investigated in the range of CH4/O2 = 3, 2, 1 and 0.5. The selectivity of C1 oxygenates and methane conversion determined at different CH4/O2 ratios are depicted in Fig. 15 and Figures S18. The methane conversion showed an increasing trend with decreasing CH4/O2 ratio, and is consistent with the reported literature [80 81 82]. In the present investigation, the methane was completely converted to products at CH4/O2 ratio of 0.5. Whereas the oxygen was fully consumed at all CH4/O2 ratios. The highest yields of methanol (2.4 %) and formaldehyde (1.2 %) was received at CH4/O2 ratio of 2 and 1, respectively. Increasing the feed oxygen concentration, the methane conversion was increased with an enhanced formation of formic acid and CO2 suggesting that high feed oxygen concentration favours overoxidation of methanol. The formic acid yield increases from 0.48 % to 3.67 % with an decrease in CH4/O2 ratio from 3:1 to 1:2 and the formic acid yield of 0.48 % was achieved at CH4/O2 ratio of 2:1. In addition, lowest selectivity of formic was noticed at CH4/O2 ratio of 2:1. 3.2.6 Reproducibility, and stability study The reproducibility of experimental runs was performed under tuned reaction conditions found in the present study in order to assess the accuracy and repeatability of the experimental data and the findings are reported in Table S8. The measured errors for reactant conversion, selectivity, and yield of different products within ± 3 %. The catalyst was subjected to a DMTM reaction for 50 h in order to test its stability over an extended length of reaction time. The performance of catalyst is displayed in Fig. 16 and Figure S19. It was found that the methanol selectivity reached the maximum value at 10 hr and decreases after 15 h. Furthermore, the methane conversion decreases from 37.89 % to 28.01 % till 40 h of reaction time and thereafter remains unchanged. The highest yield of methanol was obtained at 10 h of reaction time and decreases thereafter. 3.3 In-situ DRIFT study of methanol oxidation reaction The in-situ DRIFT spectra of methanol oxidation reaction over 20Cu/15CeZ catalysts are shown in Fig. 17 , Fig. 18 and Figure S20. The detailed peak assignment and variation with the temperature are tabulated in Table S10. The major methoxy (OCH3) IR bands were observed at 2984 cm−1, 2938 cm−1, 2830 cm−1 and 1440 cm−1 under ambient conditions corresponding to the asymmetric, symmetric stretching vibrations and –CH3 bending vibrations [83]. The IR bands corresponding to methoxy species remain prominent till 523 K and vanishes on further increasing the temperature beyond 523 K. While the CO2 band intensity at 2349 cm−1 [84] increases significantly for temperature above 473 K. However, the formate bands at 1575 cm−1 and 1365 cm−1 increase with an increase in temperature and become significant in the temperature range of 398 K to 523 K and disappear with further increase in temperature. The IR band at 1459 cm−1 corresponds to dioxymethylene (DOM) indicates immediate transformation of adsorbed formaldehyde whereas DOM further oxidizes to form formate species [85]. Moreover, the IR band appeared at 2917 cm−1 is attributed to the formation of polyoxymethylene (POM) from formaldehyde [86]. This observation suggests that methanol oxidized to formaldehyde, formic acid and further to CO2 in sequential pathway as the temperature increased. However high temperature also favors direct oxidation of methanol to CO2. Furthermore, the methanol oxidation reaction performed using fixed bed reactor at 873 K showed the formation of HCHO, HCOOH, COx, CH4 and H2. 3.4 Plausible reaction mechanism The probable reaction mechanism of oxidation of methane to methanol is shown in Fig. 19 . The reaction mechanism initiates with the adsorption of methane molecule on catalyst surface near the active oxygen species and formation of active oxygen species [46 87]. A hydrogen atom from methane is abstracted leading to the formation of methyl radical and surface hydroxyl group. The methyl group subsequently binds to oxygen attached to Cu (bis(µ-oxo) dicopper or mono-(µ-oxo) dicopper species) to form methoxy group which further gets converted to methanol on reaction with hydroxyl group and or water formed during the reaction. The methanol formed over the catalyst surface desorbs in gas phase. The adsorbed methoxy species undergoes dehydrogenation reaction to form adsorbed HCHO. The adsorbed HCHO further converts to different oxygenates following two routes. The adsorbed HCHO reacts with adsorbed oxygen to form formic acid which is adsorbed on the catalyst surface as monodentate or bidentate formate species. The formate species undergo sequential oxidation process forming COx (CO and CO2) as the final product. The CO could also be formed because of the sequential dehydrogenation of adsorbed formaldehyde species. Detection of low amount H2 in gaseous products during DMTM reaction and methanol oxidation reaction further confirms the dehydrogenation reaction. However, the contribution of dehydrogenation reaction is limited as low amount of H2 formed during the reaction. The catalyst regenerates its active oxygen sites through the redox cycle of Ce3+/Ce4+ and Cu+/Cu2+ during the DMTM reaction. 4 Conclusion The present investigation demonstrated the direct conversion of methane to methanol over CeZ, CeS and CeA supported CuO catalysts in a fixed bed reactor under varying process parameters including metal loading (Cu and Ce), temperature, WHSV and CH4/O2 ratio. The presence of various reducible copper and cerium species was ascertained using different characterisation techniques such as BET, XRD, UV–vis, py-FTIR, XPS and H2-TPR. The characterization results together with literature information indicate the formation of bis(µ-oxo) dicopper or mono-(µ-oxo) dicopper species which are deemed as the active sites for the DMTM reaction. Specifically, the XPS studies confirm the presence of various copper (Cu2+, Cu+ and Cu0) and cerium (Ce3+ and Ce4+) species. The coexistence of these various copper and cerium species established a redox cycle equilibrium (Cu+ + Ce4+ ⇌ Cu2+ + Ce3+) which controls the relative concentration of these species based on CeO2 loading. Again, on deposition of CeO2 generates lattice and adsorbed oxygen species and their ratio varied with the CeO2 loading. The presence of various cerium species induces charge imbalance, oxygen vacancies, and formation of unsaturated chemical bonds on the catalyst's surface resulting in increase of concentration of chemisorbed oxygen or weakly bonded oxygen species. The deposition of CeO2 increases Lewis’s acidity of the xCu/yCeZ composite catalysts. However, deposition of CuO induces more Lewis’s acidity and even generation of additional Lewis’s acid sites originated from exchanged copper species as a replacement of Bronsted acid sites. Moreover, the basicity of the supported Cu catalysts affected with Cu loading and support composition. The DMTM activities studies revealed the strong influence of various copper and cerium species on the methane molecule activation, and selectivity and yield of methanol. A strong relationship exists between the surface concentration of Cu2+ species bears and the activity of catalysts and higher Cu2+ species enhances methanol selectivity by preventing the methanol overoxidation to formic acid, hydroxyl radical formation and hydroxyl radical mediated oxidation of methane to methanol. In addition to Cu2+ species, the lattice-to-adsorbed oxygen ratio also played a crucial role in improving the selectivity of methanol and higher the lattice-to-adsorbed oxygen ratio enhances the methanol selectivity. The adsorbed oxygen causes overoxidation of methanol leading to the formation of oxygenates and carbon dioxide. Thus, optimum surface concentration of Cu2+ and lattice to adsorbed oxygen maximizes the yield of methanol. The process parameters also the affect the methane conversion and selectivity and yield of methanol. In the present investigation, the 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst with the highest lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio and more surface Cu2+ species concentration exhibited superior DMTM performance and provided highest yield of methanol (2.4 %) at 873 K, 1030 ml hr-1 gcat−1 and CH4/O2 ratio of 2:1. The intrinsic stability of methanol was also investigated using in-situ DRIFT studies and catalytic partial oxidation of methanol using 20Cu/15CeZ catalyst. Various adsorbed oxygenates species were identified during DRIFT studies such as methoxy species, formaldehyde derivatives, formats and COx. A plausible reaction mechanism of methane oxidation to methanol is proposed based on results obtained in the present investigation. coredata.dc:description: The direct methane to methanol (DMTM) conversion was studied in a fixed bed reactor under varying reaction parameters including temperature, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) and CH4:O2 over several CeO2-ZSM5, CeO2-SiO2 and CeO2-Al2O3 supported CuO catalysts prepared by wetness impregnation method and characterized by several techniques including N2 adsorption desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), ultraviolet visible spectroscopy (UV–vis), temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) and CO-diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFT) studies. The characterization results confirm the formation of bis(µ-oxo) dicopper or mono-(µ-oxo) dicopper species considered as the active sites for the DMTM reaction. Moreover, various copper (Cu2+, Cu+ and Cu0) and cerium (Ce3+ and Ce4+) species are coexisted in a redox cycle equilibrium (Cu+ + Ce4+ ⇌ Cu2+ + Ce3+) depending on CeO2 loading. XPS studies indicates the generation of lattice and adsorbed oxygen species on deposition of CeO2 and their ratio varied with the CeO2 loading. Moreover, the different cerium species induces charge unbalance, oxygen vacancies, and formation of unsaturated chemical bonds on the catalyst’s surface. The deposition of CeO2 and CuO incorporates more Lewis’s acid sites in xCu/yCe-ZSM5 composite catalysts and even formation of additional Lewis’s acid sites originated from exchanged copper species. The various copper and cerium species formed in the composite catalysts strongly influenced the methane molecule activation, and selectivity and yield of methanol. The surface Cu2+ species promotes the formation of methanol and prevents the methanol overoxidation forming oxygenates and carbon dioxide. In addition to the Cu2+ species, the lattice and adsorbed oxygen generated on deposition of CeO2 also influence the formation and oxidation of methanol. Thus, optimum surface concentration of Cu2+ and lattice to adsorbed oxygen maximizes the yield of methanol. The process parameters also the affect the methane conversion and methanol selectivity and yield. The methanol selectivity of 6.34 % with methane conversion of 37.89 % was achieved over 20Cu/15CeZ catalysts at 873 K, 1030 ml hr-1 gcat−1 and CH4:O2 = 2:1. A plausible reaction mechanism of oxidation of methane to methanol based on the activity results and in-situ DRFIT studies of methanol oxidation.
